citeinfo.title: Gopher Tortoise Enhanced Line-Transect Distance Sampling Survey Data from 2017-2018
citeinfo.othercit: Data associated with ENHANCING LINE-TRANSECT DISTANCE SAMPLING TO INCREASE DETECTABILITY OF GOPHER TORTOISES (GOPHERUS POLYPHEMUS) IN POPULATION SURVEYS by Heather Gaya

descript.abstract: This dataset contains locations of gopher tortoise burrows observed during enhanced line-transect distance sampling and information on transect length and nearby vegetation height. The burrow spreadsheet contains observations of gopher tortoise burrows. The transect spreadsheets contains the lengths and IDs of the transects walked during those surveys. The vegetation spreadsheet contains vegetation obstruction information. The ISU spreadsheet has information on the size and central location of intensive search plots.
descript.purpose: Data were collected to estimate the abundance of gopher tortoises using new field and analytical methods. Data may be useful for demonstrating detection difficulties of smaller burrows or for comparing to previous data collected at these sites. ELTDS surveys represent partial surveys at each site and may not be representative of the entire site's gopher tortoise population.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the data set's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.
idinfo.datacred: We thank R. I. Belcher, J. M. Fox, R. E. Joffey, E. A. Laske, and T. J. Prebyl for field assistance. This work was funded through U.S. Department of Agriculture Natural Resources Conservation Service awards 68-7482-16-544 and 68-7482-16-545. Additional funding was provided by the Joseph W. Jones Ecological Research Center. The use of animals in this study was approved by the University of Georgia's Animal Care and Use Committee (permit A2017 03-016-Y2-A0). Gopher tortoise burrows were surveyed with permission of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources and the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.
idinfo.native: The data is named Burrow_Data.csv, and Transect_Data.csv. It was produced in Microsoft Excel 2016 on an Intel Core 2.70 GHz computer running Windows 10. The data are provided in comma-separated value (.csv) format. Size: 39.67 KB

attracc.attraccr: Data were not tested for accuracy. GPS unit had 1-2 m accuracy.

dataqual.logic: All the data match up properly. There are no known errors in this dataset
dataqual.complete: The dataset only represents observations within the date range provided. It is likely not valid for inferences before or after those dates.

procstep.procdesc: we adapted the conventional gopher tortoise LTDS survey (Smith et al. 2016) for a survey with two observers, with each observer standing 2.5 m on either side of the transect. One observer navigated using a Trimble Juno T41 (1-2 m accuracy; Trimble Navigation, Ltd., Sunnyvale, CA) and searched for burrows on and near the transect. The other observer walked on the other side of the transect and searched for burrows on and near the transect. At each burrow, we obtained a GPS location, measured burrow width at 50 cm inside the opening (Martin and Layne 1987), and determined occupancy status of non-collapsed burrows. We determined occupancy by scoping each burrow with a burrow camera and classifying the burrow as either (1) occupied (tortoise observed), (2) unoccupied or (3) unknown occupancy (Smith et al. 2016). In addition to the conventional protocol, we recorded vegetation measurements at regular intervals from the beginning to the end of each transect line to estimate vegetation obstruction (Chapter 3). Prior to data analysis, we used inverse distance weighted interpolation of the point measurements in ArcMap v. 10.6.1 (Environmental Systems Research Institute, Redlands, California, USA) to create a smoothed layer of estimated vegetation density across the sampled landscape, and we extracted an estimate of vegetation obstruction (range 0-1 m) at the location of each detected burrow. To survey each ISU, we first performed the conventional LTDS protocol on the transect that crossed the intensive-search unit. We then returned to a random corner of the ISU and began our intensive search. In a direction perpendicular to the LTDS transect, observers slowly walked in tandem close enough to each other such that the area between them was thoroughly scanned; in our case, we believed that separating observers by 4m was sufficient to achieve complete coverage. All burrows newly found by the intensive search were marked with a GPS location, measured, and scoped for occupancy. We relied on GPS locations and the presence of our own footprints on burrow aprons to differentiate between newly found burrows and previously recorded burrows. We did not re-measure or confirm the occupancy status of burrows that were already found during the conventional LTDS portion of the survey.

enttyp.enttypd: Gopher tortoise burrow location and information

attr.attrdef: A number for each burrow in the dataset
Did the tortoise burrow seem active? Were there tracks, fresh poop or other signs of a tortoise maintaining the burrow?
The diameter in cm of the tortoise burrow at 50 cm deep (for adult burrows) or at the mouth of the burrow (for juvenile burrows)
Was the burrow occupied with a gopher tortoise?

edom.edomvd: Unknown; unsuccessful scoping or not measured
Yes, at least one tortoise observed

attr.attrdef: Was the burrow found during the standard LTDS portion of the survey (1) or during an intensive search (0)?

edom.edomvd: Not seen initially; only seen during intensive searching
Found during the standard LTDS portion of the survey

attr.attrdef: Latitude of the point in DD
Longitude of the point in DD
Northing of the point (NAD 1983 UTM 17 N)
Easting of the point (NAD 1983 UTM 17 N)
What site was this tortoise found on?

attrdomv.udom: Names represent the site name where the tortoise burrow was found

enttyp.enttypd: Intensive search unit location and information

attr.attrdef: ID of the intensive search unit
Site name where the survey was conducted

attrdomv.udom: Names represent the site where the survey was conducted

attr.attrdef: The intensive searches are all rectangles - this is the length of one side of the box
The total area of the intensive search unit in meters
X coordinate of the ISU centroid in DD
Y coordinate of the ISU centroid in DD

enttyp.enttypd: Vegetation data for enhanced line transect distance sampling surveys

attr.attrdef: Object id # for the point
The vegetation value measured at that location. Represents the vegetation obstruction at that point - AKA the vegetation height in cm
Percent cover of vegetation at that location
Was wiregrass present at that vegetation point?
Time points were taken

attrdomv.udom: The time (24 hour format) when the points were taken

attr.attrdef: Latitude in decimal degrees
Longitude in decimal degrees
Northing of the point (NAD 1983 UTM 17N)
Easting of the point (NAD 1983 UTM 17N)
Site name where the survey was conducted

attrdomv.udom: Site name where the survey was conducted

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attr.attrdef: Object ID #
Site name where the survey was conducted

attrdomv.udom: Site name where the survey was conducted

attr.attrdef: Transect ID
Alternative transect ID #
Length of the transect in meters

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
